intro: Castilleja litoralis, commonly known as the coastal cholla or coast cholla, is a flowering plant native to the coastal regions of California and Baja California. It is a member of the Orobanchaceae family, commonly known as the broomrape family, and is characterized by its parasitic growth habit. The plant typically has a woody stem with spiny branches and produces small, yellowish to reddish flowers. It thrives in sandy or gravelly soils and is often found in coastal scrub habitats. Castilleja litoralis plays a role in local ecosystems by providing nectar for pollinators and serving as a food source for certain wildlife.
